tit.cmt: ※安土桃山から江戸初期にかけての仏師「康正」もローマ字にすると"Kosho"になるので、区別のため漢字も併記しています。

sen.j: 康勝（こうしょう、生没年不詳）は、鎌倉時代の仏師。
sen.e: Kosho (康勝) was a "busshi" (sculptor of Buddhist statues), living in the Kamakura period, but it is not known when he was born and gone.

sen.j: 建久8 - 9年（1197 - 1198年）、東寺南大門の金剛力士（仁王）像（現存せず）の造立に運慶らとともに携わったのが、史料上の初見である。
sen.e: His first appearnce on the historical material was about his involvement in the construction, with Unkei and other sculptors, of the Statue of Kongo Rikishi (Nio) at Nandaimon gate of To-ji Temple, but the statue is not existent any more.

sen.j: 運慶が一門の仏師を率いて建暦2年（1212年）に完成させた興福寺北円堂復興造仏にあたっては、四天王のうちの多聞天像を担当しているが、この四天王像は現在、所在不明である（現在、興福寺北円堂に安置する四天王像は全く時代の違う平安時代初期のもの）。
sen.e: When the Buddhist Statues in Hokuendo hall of Kofuku-ji Temple were completely reconstructed in 1212 by Unkei and other "busshi" of his school, Kosho was in charge of "Tamon-ten zo" (Statue of Tamon-ten), which is one of "Shitenno zo" (Four Statues of the Deities Protecting Buddhism), but now the whereabouts of these four statues is unknown, and Shitenno zo enshrined at present in Hokuendo hall of Kofuku-ji Temple are utterly different ones made in the early Heian period.

When the Buddhist statues in Hokuendo hall of Kofuku-ji Temple were completely reconstructed in 1212 by Unkei and other busshi of his school, Kosho was in charge of statue of Tamonten (Vaisravana), which is one of Shitenno (four guardian kings), but now the whereabouts of the statue of Shitenno is unknown (the statue of Shitenno enshrined at present in Hokuendo hall of Kofuku-ji Temple are different ones made in the early Heian period).

sen.j: 現存する康勝の作品としては、日本の肖像彫刻として屈指の著名作である空也上人像（六波羅蜜寺蔵）、後世の弘法大師像の規範となった東寺御影堂の弘法大師（空海）像などがある。
sen.e: Kosho's existent masterpieces include "the Statue of Kuya Shonin" (a collection of Rokuharamitsu-ji Temple), which is one of the most famous masterpieces of all image statues in Japan, & "the Statue of Kobodaishi (Kukai)" in Mieido hall of To-ji Temple, which became the model for the statues of Kobodaishi in later years.

Kosho's existing masterpieces include "the Statue of Kuya Shonin" (a collection of Rokuharamitsu-ji Temple), which is one of the most famous masterpieces of all image statues in Japan, & "the Statue of Kobodaishi (Kukai)" in Mieido hall of To-ji Temple, which became the model for the statues of Kobodaishi in later years.

Kosho's existing masterpieces include the statue of Kuya Shonin (a collection of Rokuharamitsu-ji Temple), which is one of the most famous masterpieces of all image statues in Japan, and the statue of Kobo Daishi (a posthumous title of the priest Kukai) in Mieido hall of To-ji Temple, which became the model for the statues of Kobo Daishi in later years.
sen.cmt: 用語集に合わせました。

sen.j: 東大寺念仏堂の地蔵菩薩坐像（康清作）の銘記から、この像が造られた嘉禎3年（1237年）より以前に康勝が没していることが知られる。
sen.e: "Jizo-Bosatsu zazo" (The Buddhist Statue of a Sitting Guardian Deity of Children) in Nenbutsudo hall of Todai-ji Temple is a work of "Kosei," and the inscription in the statue suggests that Kosho died before 1237 when the statue was made.

The inscription of the seated statue of Jizo Bosatsu (Jizo Bodhisattva) (made by Kosei) in Nenbutsudo hall of Todai-ji Temple suggests Kosho died before 1237 when the statue was completed.

sen.j: 6体の阿弥陀仏は「南無阿弥陀仏」の6字が仏と化したことを意味する。
sen.e: The six "Amidabutsu" statues symbolize that each Chinese character of "南無阿弥陀仏," which reads "Namuamidabutsu," changes into the Buddhist image.
The six "Amidabutsu" statues symbolize that each Chinese character of "南無阿弥陀仏," reading "Namuamidabutsu," changes into a Buddhist image.
The six Amidabutsu symbolize that each Chinese character of 'Namu Amidabutsu' (a single, sincere call upon the name of Amida, 南無阿弥陀仏) changes into a Buddhist image.
